video.title: Fornite: Battle Royale and Dusk (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text: Our topic for the day is early access shooters.

For it is very important that shooters undergo
rigorous testing before they&#39;re officially

released, it&#39;s all too easy for something
to go wrong with the formula of &quot;click on
the thing and the thing dies&quot;.

What if you click on the thing and the thing
doesn&#39;t die?

What if you click on the thing and give the
thing a bunch of flowers?

The only possible solution is to let people
pay for it before it&#39;s finished and make sure

they&#39;re good and sick of it by the time it&#39;s
to releasable standard.

So let&#39;s start with Fortnite: Battle Royale
with cheese.

Playerunknown&#39;s Bobcat Goldthwaite is of course
more popular than the last pair of socks at

the wanking factory, and when something attains
that level of success there have to be a few

less well known alternatives so that hipsters
can say that they&#39;re way better actually but
you wouldn&#39;t understand &#39;cos you&#39;re a pleb.

Apparently Fortnite was already some co-op
survival shooty crafty bollocks that they

added a Battle Royale mode to when they smelled
the whiff of opportunity coming off PlayerUnknown&#39;s

Buggy Glitchfest, but who the fuck cares &#39;cos
the base game costs money and the Battle Royale

mode is free to play, and frankly I wasn&#39;t
planning to spend more on shooty funtimes
than the bus fare to the homeless shelter.

It&#39;s a pretty faithful copy paste of the mechanics
- you wait for 100 players to join while running

around an island where no one can die competing
to find the most creative way to annoy each

other, and then we cut to a plane passing
over an island and decide when we&#39;re going
to parachute out.

Loot houses, last one standing wins, white
circle crouch in a bush and have a smoke,

blue circle keep serpentining towards where
the line&#39;s pointing at and try not to cry.

Where it differs is in the much smaller map
and related lack of vehicles, and the more

cartoony art style, meaning the men have big
chins and the women have big bums and guns

hover off the ground slowly spinning like
they&#39;re being sold on the shopping channel.

If you&#39;ve ever ragequit Playerunknown&#39;s Burly
Gentlemen because you realised too late that

the two pixels in a distant window in the
middle of a bombed out city was actually a

sniper, then Fortnite might be the alternative
for you, as the larger than life art style

removes a lot of the &quot;Playing Where&#39;s Wally
for your life&quot; aspect of Playerunknown&#39;s Blatantly
Garish.

You can&#39;t even go prone, which is one way
of ending the argument over whether it&#39;s a
good idea or not.

The more confined map means the games are
shorter and you can get into action more often,

and action can mean interesting circle strafing
shotgun contests as well as fucking sniping
duels.

So maybe it is better than Playerunknown&#39;s
Bush Getaway if you&#39;ve run out of podcasts

and aren&#39;t willing to sit quietly in a hedge
for half an hour, but then again, the smaller

map also means that if you haven&#39;t got a decent
weapon inside the first minute or so then

you&#39;re fucked, because everything will be
looted by then.

Also Fortnite has construction mechanics presumably
transplanted from the base game that I&#39;m not

sure I like, because more than once I&#39;ve seen
endgames descend into two or three dudes aggressively

building towers at each other because no one&#39;s
prepared to risk coming outside.

So now as well as gitting gud at the combat
and exploring and shit we have to git gud
at building towers ridiculously fast.
Also, fuck traps.

You can pick up an item that traps a section
of floor, other players can&#39;t see it and it
instantly kills them.

That&#39;s not pitting skill against skill, that&#39;s
just &quot;Oh, you walked into a room?
WELL FUCK YOU.
That&#39;ll teach you to wipe your feet.&quot;

Oh but it is early access so maybe they&#39;ll
have changed that by next week or added a
chocolate fountain, who the fuck knows.

Let&#39;s talk about another Early Access shooter
called Dusk, yet another deliberately old-style

nostalgia game, in this new age where pixel
art is passe and it&#39;s now early 3D that the

nostalgia nerds demand between mouthfuls of
barely-chewed 90&#39;s breakfast cereal.

Dusk is deliberately citing Quake and Doom
and Unreal and everything else that felt like

any title longer than six letters was just
showing off.

Dusk is not to be confused with Strafe, of
course, another recent game evoking the same

era of shooters, &#39;cos it&#39;s got a completely
different name.
Alright, fine, it&#39;s also not a roguelike.

Which is for the better, to my mind, hopefully
we&#39;re growing out of this &quot;let&#39;s make everything

a fucking roguelike&quot; phase of gaming, replay
value is all very well but with random levels

you&#39;re also sacrificing any opportunity you
had to tell a story with the environment.

In Dusk, you can have a level set on a farm
and be all like &quot;Hey, this actually looks
like a farm!

A farm pieced together from a selection of
differently-sized cardboard boxes that are

all coloured like they got fished out of the
septic tank behind a bran tasting facility
but recognisably a farm nonetheless!&quot;

Which brings me to the specific problem with
this kind of nostalgic recreation of old style

graphics - while 16 bit pixel art can still
conceivably look good, early 3D invariably

looks like crude papercraft that someone assembled
using only their sphincter muscles, and I
think there&#39;s a tendency to hide behind that.

But ultimately even the thickest layer of
nostalgic graphical manure can&#39;t hide good
old fashioned bad level design.

And some of Dusk&#39;s maps remind me of those
CDs of 500 custom Doom and Quake levels you

used to get from car boot sales in jewel cases
with photocopied inserts, the ones that contained

levels that some student had smashed together
from plain rectangles on the day they figured

out how the level editor&#39;s rotate function
worked.

What I&#39;m saying is, I&#39;m actually old enough
to remember the Quake era, and if Dusk had

come out around them it wouldn&#39;t have been
in the upper tier of shooters of the time.

This ain&#39;t a Quake, this is closer to a Chasm:
The Rift or a Redneck Rampage, although I&#39;ll

concede it&#39;s at least on a higher tier than
Blood 2: The Chosen.

Wow, this is all starting to sound needlessly
mean, isn&#39;t it.

There&#39;s like one and a half guys working on
this thing, Yahtz, you&#39;re supposed to shower

it with condescending praise if it so much
as has gravity set to go the right way up.
Fine.

There are some areas where Dusk absolutely
nails it, for one the atmosphere and for two
the combat.

The monsters range in design from Playmobil
farm animals to stick figures that move like

they&#39;re on roller skates, and to my mind a
few too many of them fire projectiles that

move in randomized directions so you have
to basically roll a dice on whether your fat

arse is about to dodge the right way, but
the weapons are good.

They&#39;ve got that all important visceral kick
to them that makes for fun gameplay, and since

you&#39;re using them an average of about twelve
billion times per minute, good weapons and
action can be a shooter&#39;s saving grace.

Leaping over an enemy and blowing them away
with dual-wielded shotguns is going to be

fun even if the enemy looks like a toilet
roll tube with pipe cleaners stuck to it.

Having said that, I wouldn&#39;t recommend getting
Dusk now, nor would I recommend any linear

single player game going early access because
it&#39;s just sacrificing the first impression,

and after you&#39;ve finished the two available
chapters of the promised three, you&#39;ll be

left blindly groping for a climax like there
was a sudden power cut at the backstreet massage
parlour.

Sort of underlines the inherent problem with
reviewing early access games, but as a great

Youtube channel once said, fuck you, it&#39;s
January.

What else am I gonna review, the smell of
my dog&#39;s farts?

Two stars, bold and earthy with subtle notes
of toilet water.
